virtuals.subtitle: PHP: June ’95, clearly old as hell, only used by dinosaurs.

paragraphs.name: 60b3
paragraphs.text: Fantastic post, Simon. As a fifteen year PHP dev, (and tech C-Suite these days), I can’t believe my eyes haven’t rolled out of my head the number of times I’ve heard of PHP’s untimely demise. The one thing you left out is comparing the relative ages of the two languages.

content.subtitle: PHP: June ’95, clearly old as hell, only used by dinosaurs.

paragraphs.name: 21ce
paragraphs.text: LoL Incompetent PHP devs. As a PHP developer I have to say that I struggled a lot prior to jumping in Laravel. Things are much organized now. Similar to Rails in some senses. As for Node, as I can understand it is very hyped, just like Rails was before some time. Let us see what the future holds for it. I ain’t going with it as I have to go with Java now :P

Node’s superiority is evident because everyone knows that single-threaded, asynchronous, programs are better by default. Faster…

content.subtitle: It’s well known that PHP is a dead programming language and that its 22-year-old ecosystem is effectively useless now that we have Node and…

paragraphs.name: 2f88
paragraphs.text: It’s well known that PHP is a dead programming language and that its 22-year-old ecosystem is effectively useless now that we have Node and its fancy new asynchronous frameworks. Node’s superiority is evident because everyone knows that single-threaded, asynchronous, programs are better by default. Faster. Stronger, even.

paragraphs.name: 85bd
paragraphs.text: $caption = ‘PHP devs can’t find jobs to support their families’;

paragraphs.name: f74c
paragraphs.text: PHP developers are not in demand at all. After ~22 years, all companies using PHP immediately gave up on it as soon as Node v0.0.1 was released because it was instantly the better application environment. Furthermore, everyone knows that to be a successful new startup (unlike Slack) you have to create Node-based web APIs backed by MongoDB. It’s simply impossible to be successful otherwise.
